title: Do high school teachers make more than elementary? - Quora

response.answer_text: In the US salaries are negotiated been the union and the school board within each school district. There are 10000 school districts in the US. Many are unified school districts (K-12). In these districts it would be highly unlikely that an elementary school teacher would have a different salary then a high school teacher. Some contracts allow districts to offer bonuses or higher pay for in demand subjects so some math and science teachers might get a little more. I grew up and worked in the suburbs of Chicago in which the elementary schools were run by a separate school district with a separate school board and teacher contract then the high school they fed into. In most of these school districts the high school teachers had a contract that paid them often 20% then the elementary school teachers. I don’t know if there are any other places that have districts like this. It seemed very inefficient to have a school district with 4 elementary schools, and two middle schools with its own school board and superintendent fees into a separate school district of one or two high schools with its own school board and superintendent.

Generally, no. In most school districts, teachers at all levels make the same. There are, however, some examples of this not being entirely true. Many districts allow teachers to “sell” their prep time to teach additional classes. Because of scheduling, this basically never works for elementary teachers, but can be used by secondary teachers to make more money. There are also opportunities for high school teachers to take on extra duties for extra pay that are not generally available to elementary teachers (though they are on occasion). This includes things like coaching, mentoring, advising a club, chaperoning events, etc. There are probably other examples, some of them more or less obvious to outside notice, but these are two major examples I am personally aware of.
No. Exception: coaches or those involved in afterschool programs. I am not aware of any public school which explicitly glorifies one grade level over another.

According to the National Careers Service website, Primary and Secondary School Teachers both earn between £22,500 (starting salary) to £66,750 per year on average. Those working in London may get an additional weighting applied, depending on location. While I accept the salaries listed, don’t believe the “hours worked” - nearly fell off my sofa laughing at the figures listed. Teachers put in somewhere between 50 and 100% extra hours above and beyond what they’re paid for in marking homework, creating and updating lesson plans and continuous professional development, even during the Summer holidays. My mother worked as a supply teacher filling in for planned and unplanned absences in local Primary Schools. While she only worked a day or two a week most of the time she still put in a lot of effort outside of classroom hours.
In US public schools, no. I can’t speak for private schools or schools in other countries. The amount of work is probably about the same, it’s just the kind of work that differs.

No! If you go to the human resource page of the district you are applying to there will be a page where generic salaries are posted. Salary is gauged by experience, not age group taught, and should be uniform across the district.

No, it goes by how many years you've been working for D.O.E. Also education. Masters degree required in public schools. Charter schools vary some only require B.A. Anyway Pcredits are classes you take for pay raises. If you get 30 credits above Master's you get another pay raise. Every year you get a small pay raise on anniversary of hiring date.
